thread.title: Man claims Atlas Hard Cider bottle exploded, shredded his legs
thread.title_full: Man claims Atlas Hard Cider bottle exploded, shredded his legs | OregonLive.com

author: Aimee Green | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Man claims Atlas Hard Cider bottle exploded, shredded his legs
text:
A worker who says a bottle of Atlas Hard Cider exploded and sent pieces of glass flying into his legs filed a $10,000 lawsuit this week against the Bend beverage maker.
Peter Leinweber claims that Atlas Hard Cider Co. was aware that it had a problem with the bottles before he was injured on Sept. 7, 2014.
Excessive pressure would build up and the bottles would suddenly burst, but the company didn't "recall the dangerous batch(es) of hard cider products for fear of losing face in the marketplace," the lawsuit claims.
Leinweber lists the company and founder Dan McCoy as defendants in the Multnomah County Circuit Court suit. The company didn't return requests seeking comment Tuesday.
The company was founded three years ago and is part of Oregon's latest boutique alcohol craze .
Leinweber's suit says he was working a "product booth" when a customer approached and told him that a bottle of Atlas cider had exploded in his cellar. The customer exchanged a bottle that was leaking -- and an hour or two later, that bottle exploded, the suit states.
Leinweber suffered four cuts to his legs and received 11 sutures, his suit states. One of the cuts later became infected, and he sought additional care, including antibiotic treatment, according to the suit.
The cider became unstable after certain batches experienced "a secondary fermentation ... within the bottle causing the development of dangerous and excess pressures," the suit alleges.
In August, Ohio-based hard cider maker Angry Orchard recalled some of its product after similar reports of bursting bottles caused by re-fermentation.
Leinweber is seeking $2,033 in medical expenses and $7,966 for pain and suffering. His suit, however, states he might seek up to $75,000 for pain and suffering.
He says in the suit that the company didn't provide him with workers' compensation coverage.
Portland attorney J. William Savage is representing Leinweber.
